user_query: If my registration is inactive, can I still vote at my polling place
dewey_match: Can I vote if my registration is inactive?
response: If your voter registration is marked as inactive, you can still vote. A voter is marked inactive if they have not voted for two consecutive federal election cycles and haven’t responded to a county notice about their registration. If that’s your status, you can still vote on election day. You’ll just have to sign a form confirming your eligibility when you visit your polling place.

user_query: I changed my address but my voter registration isn’t updated. How do I vote?
dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response: If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address. For more details, you can refer to the "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-registration/update-my-registration.html" “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: Who is Stacy Garrity?
dewey_match: Who is Stacy Garrity?
response: Stacy Garrity, a Republican, is Pennsylvania's state treasurer. She is a retired U.S. Army Reserve colonel and a graduate of Bloomsburg University of Pennsylvania. She was deployed three times, earning two Bronze Stars and the Legion of Merit award. Following her military service, Garrity worked at Global Tungsten & Powders as vice president of government affairs and industry liaison. Garrity was elected Pennsylvania state treasurer in 2020 and is running for reelection. In her bid for a second four-year term, she has focused on transparency, pledged to return unclaimed property, and said she wants to reduce wasteful state spending.

user_query: Who is Erin McClelland?
dewey_match: Who is Erin McClelland?
response: Erin McClelland is a former small business owner and the Democratic nominee for Pennsylvania treasurer. She won her primary election on April 23, 2024, defeating the party-backed candidate, Ryan Bizzarro. McClelland has previously run for Congress and has experience as a substance abuse counselor and project manager for the Allegheny County Department of Human Services. She will face incumbent Republican Stacy Garrity in the upcoming general election.

user_query: Who is Malcolm Kenyatta?
dewey_match: Who is Malcolm Kenyatta?
response: Malcolm Kenyatta is a state representative from Philadelphia and the Democratic nominee for Pennsylvania auditor general. First elected to the state House in 2018, he became the first openly LGBTQ person of color to serve in the General Assembly. Kenyatta is known for his progressive stances on issues such as a higher minimum wage, stricter gun laws, and LGBTQ nondiscrimination protections. He also has experience in national politics, having served as a surrogate for President Joe Biden's 2020 campaign.

user_query: Who is Tim DeFoor?
dewey_match: Who is Tim DeFoor?
response: Tim DeFoor is the current auditor general of Pennsylvania, having taken office in January 2021. DeFoor is the first person of color to win a state row office in Pennsylvania and the first Republican to hold the auditor general position since 1997. He is running for reelection in 2024. In his announcement that he would seek another four years in office, DeFoor said his first term focused on transforming the auditor general’s office in a nonpartisan way, and that his second would center on “ensuring the job gets done.” DeFoor has primarily stuck to the office’s required functions: auditing local pension plans and volunteer firefighters’ relief associations, and making sure county offices and district courts handle state money properly.

user_query: What does the auditor general do?
dewey_match: What does the state auditor general do?
response: The Pennsylvania auditor general — also called a comptroller, state auditor, or auditor of public accounts in other states — monitors the spending of public funds. In Pennsylvania, the department describes itself as the “chief fiscal watchdog of the commonwealth.” The agency performs financial and performance audits of everything from district courts and municipal pension plans, to state-owned universities and commonwealth departments. The reports it regularly releases detail its findings and recommend fixes and policies.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: How is it determined which presidential candidate wins in a state?
dewey_match: How is it determined which presidential candidate wins in a state?
response: Each state has a specific number of electoral votes. In most states, the candidate who wins the popular vote receives all of the electoral votes; "https://fairvote.org/archives/the_electoral_college-maine_nebraska/" the exceptions are Maine and Nebraska. These electoral votes are then used to officially elect the president through the Electoral College. The candidate who receives a majority of the electoral votes nationwide, which is 270 out of 538, wins the presidential election.

user_query: How is ballot position determined in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: How is ballot position determined in Pennsylvania?
response: In Pennsylvania, ballot position for state House candidates is determined through a random drawing of numbered tiles, as prescribed by the state's Election Code. Candidates or their proxies select a tile from a bag containing numbers 31 to 40. The lower the number drawn, the higher the candidate appears on the ballot. This process aims to ensure fairness in the selection of ballot order and mitigate any potential advantages associated with appearing at the top of the ballot. According to election officials, this method is used to balance out the potential impact of ballot order on candidates' chances of performing well in the election.

user_query: Can I vote if my registration is expired
dewey_match: My voting registration has expired. Can I still vote?
response: Voter registration in Pennsylvania doesn't have an expiration date, but your status can become inactive under certain circumstances. If you moved and didn't update your registration, if you haven't responded to official election mail or if you don't vote for two consecutive federal elections, your registration status can change to inactive which could lead to you being removed from the voter rolls. Use the "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/voterregistrationstatus.aspx" Find Voter Registration Status form on the Pennsylvania Department of State website to check your voter status. If you believe you are still eligible to vote, you can do so in person on Election Day via a "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/provisional-ballot.html" provisional ballot. A provisional ballot is used when poll workers have questions about a voter’s eligibility. You can see whether your provisional ballot was accepted by visiting the state’s website, "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/Pages/ProvisionalBallotSearch.aspx" which has a ballot search function.

user_query: Are electronic ballots safe?
dewey_match: Are electronic ballots safe?
response: In Pennsylvania, each  voting machine is tested at both the federal and state levels before going into service, and they are tested again before each election to ensure they work properly. Pennsylvania counties also conduct two types of post-election analyses: a 2% statistical sample required by state statute, and a statewide risk-limiting audit. Risk-limiting audits are scientifically designed procedures that use statistical methods to confirm election outcomes and to detect possible interference. Lastly, all voting machines produce paper ballots that can be audited, allowing election officials to verify the accuracy of the outcome  after voting has concluded.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: How do I make sure my ballot is counted?
dewey_match: How do I make sure my ballot is counted?
response: Whether you are voting by mail or in person, to ensure your ballot is counted in Pennsylvania, it's crucial to carefully follow all instructions when completing it, and in the case of a mail ballot, returning it. For mail-in or absentee ballots, double-check that you've filled out the ballot correctly and enclosed it in the provided secrecy envelope.  After you've dated and signed your ballot, follow the outlined procedures for returning the ballot, whether it's by mail or at a "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" designated drop-off location. Additionally, you can track the "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" status of your ballot through Pennsylvania's official ballot tracking system to ensure it has been received and accepted by the election officials. In order to be counted, your ballot must be received by your county election office by 8 p.m. on Nov. 5 (Election Day). If you are voting in person, follow the instructions on your voting machine. If you have any concerns or questions about your ballot, you can reach out to your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/contact-us/contact-your-election-officials.html" county election office for assistance.

user_query: What are the current voter ID requirements in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: What are the current voter ID requirements in Pennsylvania?
response: In Pennsylvania, voters must show "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/new-voters.html" proof of identification when voting at a polling place for the first time. Approved forms of photo identification include a Pennsylvania driver's license, a PennDOT ID card, IDs issued by any commonwealth or U.S. government agency, a U.S. passport, a U.S. Armed Forces ID, student IDs, and employee IDs. If voters do not have a photo ID, they can present non-photo identification that includes their name and address, such as a confirmation issued by the county voter registration office, non-photo ID issued by the commonwealth, non-photo ID issued by the U.S. government, firearm permit, current utility bill, current bank statement, current paycheck, or government check.

user_query: My voting registration has expired. Can I still vote?
dewey_match: My voting registration has expired. Can I still vote?
response: Voter registration in Pennsylvania doesn't have an expiration date, but your status can become inactive under certain circumstances. If you moved and didn't update your registration, if you haven't responded to official election mail or if you don't vote for two consecutive federal elections, your registration status can change to inactive which could lead to you being removed from the voter rolls. Use the "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/voterregistrationstatus.aspx" Find Voter Registration Status form on the Pennsylvania Department of State website to check your voter status. If you believe you are still eligible to vote, you can do so in person on Election Day via a "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/provisional-ballot.html" provisional ballot. A provisional ballot is used when poll workers have questions about a voter’s eligibility. You can see whether your provisional ballot was accepted by visiting the state’s website, "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/Pages/ProvisionalBallotSearch.aspx" which has a ballot search function.

This type of ballot is for emergency situations only, such as an unexpected illness, disability, or last-minute absence from your municipality. You can "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Resources/Documents/PADOS_EmergencyAbsenteeBallotApplication_English.pdf" request an Emergency Absentee Ballot beginning at 5 p.m. the Tuesday before the election. Additionally, if you are unable to pick up or return your emergency ballot, you can authorize a representative to do so on your behalf.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: I forgot to register
dewey_match: Can I vote if I forgot to register?
response: You must be registered to vote in advance of Election Day in Pennsylvania; the state does not offer same-day registration. The deadline to register for the Nov. 5 general election was Oct. 21, 2024. If you did not register, you will not be able to vote.

user_query: Can I register to vote on election day
dewey_match: Can I vote on Election Day if I haven't registered yet?
response: You cannot vote on Election Day in Pennsylvania if you have not registered to vote. To be eligible, you must register by the deadline, which was Oct. 21 for the Nov. 5 election.

user_query: ¿Cómo puedo solicitar una boleta de voto por correo?
dewey_match: How do I request a mail ballot?
response: Puede solicitar una "https://pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/recursos-en-espanol/voter-support-spanish/mail-and-absentee-ballot-spanish.html" boleta por correo en Pensilvania en línea en el "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote.html" sitio web del Departamento de Estado, en persona en la oficina electoral de su condado, o por correo. Las solicitudes para votar por correo en las elecciones generales de 2024 deben ser recibidas por la oficina electoral de su condado antes de las 5 p.m. del 29 de octubre. Debe proporcionar una identificación adecuada para solicitar una "https://pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/recursos-en-espanol/voter-support-spanish/mail-and-absentee-ballot-spanish.html" boleta por correo. Las opciones aceptables incluyen una licencia de conducir válida de Pensilvania o una tarjeta de identificación válida de PennDOT, o los últimos cuatro dígitos de un número de Seguro Social. También puede usar una identificación de empleado con foto de una institución pública o privada acreditada de Pensilvania, como un colegio o universidad. Para obtener una lista completa de las formas aprobadas de identificación, consulte el "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote.html" sitio web del Departamento de Estado. Puede solicitar una "https://pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/recursos-en-espanol/voter-support-spanish/mail-and-absentee-ballot-spanish.html" boleta por correo de una sola vez o ser agregado a la lista de solicitudes anuales, lo que significa que recibirá una solicitud cada año. Si encuentra algún problema o tiene más preguntas, puede comunicarse con la línea directa del Departamento de Estado al 1-877-VOTESPA para obtener asistencia.

response: To fill out your mai ballot in Pennsylvania, use blue or black ink and follow these key steps: First, complete your ballot by marking your choices clearly. user_query: What are the key responsibilities of the Pennsylvania State Treasurer?
dewey_match: What are the key responsibilities of the Pennsylvania State Treasurer?
response: The Pennsylvania state treasurer is responsible for managing state dollars, which includes investing savings, managing withdrawals, and ensuring bills are paid. The treasurer oversees approximately $50 billion in state savings and sits on the boards of the two public sector pension funds, SERS and PSERS. Additional duties include reporting on state finances, advocating for fiscal policies, and administering various tax-free savings programs, such as Keystone Scholars. The office also disburses payments for unemployment compensation and manages a program for recouping unclaimed property.

user_query: My voter status is inactive
dewey_match: Can I vote if my registration is inactive?
response: If your voter registration is marked as inactive, you can still vote. A voter is marked inactive if they have not voted for two consecutive federal election cycles and haven’t responded to a county notice about their registration. If that’s your status, you can still vote on election day. You’ll just have to sign a form confirming your eligibility when you visit your polling place.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: I just moved. Where should I vote?
dewey_match: I just moved. Where should I vote?
response: The Pennsylvania Department of State provides the "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-registration/update-my-registration.html#:~:text=The%20following%20guidelines%20cover%20situations%20in%20which%20you%20move%20or%20change%20your%20address%20close%20to%20an%20election." following guidance: To Pennsylvania from another state, you must be a resident of Pennsylvania and your election district for at least 30 days before the next election to be able to vote in Pennsylvania. Within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before an election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. Fill out a change of address form at the polling place to update your voter registration to your new address. If you moved within Pennsylvania more than 30 days before an election but did not update your registration, you can vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. If you moved within the same county, you must tell the election officials at the polling place of your new address. They will update your voter registration and send you a new voter registration card. If you moved to a different county, you need to fill out a form telling us your new address and the county where you moved. After the election, the county election office for both your old and new addresses will update your voter registration. You will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address.

user_query: Can I vote if my registration is inactive?
dewey_match: Can I vote if my registration is inactive?
response: If your voter registration is marked as inactive, you can still vote. A voter is marked inactive if they have not voted for two consecutive federal election cycles and haven’t responded to a county notice about their registration. If that’s your status, you can still vote on election day. You’ll just have to sign a form confirming your eligibility when you visit your polling place.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: Can I vote at any voting location ?
dewey_match: Can I vote at any polling place?
response: No, you must vote at your designated polling place in Pennsylvania. If you arrive at the wrong polling location, you will need to go to the correct one to cast your vote. However, if you believe you are eligible to vote at the wrong location, you may request to vote using a provisional ballot, which will be counted if election officials confirm your eligibility. You can "https://www.pa.gov/en/services/vote/find-your-local-polling-place.html" find your polling place online on the Department of State website.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: Can I vote at any polling place?
dewey_match: Can I vote at any polling place?
response: No, you must vote at your designated polling place in Pennsylvania. If you arrive at the wrong polling location, you will need to go to the correct one to cast your vote. user_query: Can I submit a write in name on my ballot?
dewey_match: Can I submit a write in name on my ballot?
response: Yes, you can submit a write-in name on your ballot in Pennsylvania. You need to manually write the candidate's name in the space provided for write-in candidates and "https://www.butlercountypa.gov/204/Write-in-Voting" fill in the oval completely. "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/dos/newsroom/covering-pennsylvania-elections-101.html#accordion-7ea5b16d6a-item-d80e31b7b9:~:text=Voters%20should%20also%20be%20aware%20that%20the%20name%20of%20the%20candidate%20they%20write%20in%20must%20be%20spelled%20correctly%20to%20be%20counted%2C%20as%20the%C2%A0Pennsylvania%20Election%20Code%20requires%20that%20votes%20be%20counted%20exactly%20as%20they%20are%20spelled%20on%20the%20ballot.%C2%A0" Make sure to spell the candidate's name correctly and legibly to ensure that your write-in vote is accurately recorded. If you have any questions about the write-in process or need assistance, you can contact your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/contact-us/contact-your-election-officials.html" county election office for guidance.

user_query: What else do I need to know to vote in person?
dewey_match: What else do I need to know to vote in person?
response: The first time you vote, you must bring a photo or non-photo ID. After your first time voting, you do not need to show ID. To find your polling place, visit the "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Pages/default.aspx" Pennsylvania Department of State's website. In Pennsylvania, polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. The busiest times of day to vote are in the morning and evening. If you are in line before or at the time the polls close, you will be allowed to cast your vote. If you have a question, you can ask a poll worker at your voting location. You can learn more about the voting system in your county, as well as the candidates and measures on your ballot, by reaching out to your county election office.

user_query: What is a provisional ballot and when would I need to use one?
dewey_match: What is a provisional ballot and when would I need to use one?
response: A "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/provisional-ballot.html" provisional ballot is used when county election officials need more time to determine a voter's eligibility. You may need to use a provisional ballot if your name is not in the poll book, if you are required to show ID but cannot, if your eligibility is challenged, if there is a special court order related to your registration status, if there is a special court order to extend voting hours, or if you believe you are registered in a political party but your voter record indicates otherwise (for primary elections only). It's a way to ensure your vote is recorded while your eligibility is being determined.

user_query: What is the difference between attorney general candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between attorney general candidates?
response: The candidates for attorney general belong to different political parties: Eugene DePasquale is a Democrat and Dave Sunday is a Republican. The attorney general represents the interests of the state and the public, and defends Pennsylvania’s laws in court. DePasquale says he would use the office to protect abortion access in Pennsylvania. Sunday does not believe the state constitution guarantees a right to abortion access. He said at a debate he will “follow the law, whatever that law is, as determined by the legislature.” Sunday is the elected district attorney in York County. DePasquale has never worked as a prosecutor, defense lawyer, or trial lawyer. Take our "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/10/pennsylvania-election-2024-attorney-general-candidates-quiz/" PA attorney general candidate quiz to see which major party candidate for Pennsylvania attorney general most closely aligns with what matters to you.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

response: If your voter registration is marked as inactive, you can still vote. user_query: What are the key rules to remember when filling out a mail-in ballot?
dewey_match: What are the key rules to remember when filling out a mail-in ballot?
response: When filling out a mail-in ballot, it's crucial to follow the provided instructions carefully. Use blue or black ink to fill out your ballot. Seal the ballot in the inner "secrecy" envelope (labeled "official election ballot") and do not write on this envelope. Once you've properly sealed the inner envelope, place it in the outer envelope and seal that. Remember to sign and date below the voter declaration on the outer envelope, ensuring that the date follows the standard U.S. month-day-year format. Additionally, check your county's election website for postage requirements, as some counties may require paid postage for mail-in ballots.

user_query: Can felons vote in PA elections?
dewey_match: Can felons vote in PA elections?
response: Yes, individuals with "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/your-rights-and-the-law/criminal-status-and-voting.html" felony convictions in Pennsylvania can register and vote "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Register-to-Vote/Pages/Convicted-Felon,-Misdemeanant-or-Pretrial-Detainee.aspx" if they meet certain criteria. If they are currently confined in a penal institution for a felony conviction and will not be released until after the next election, they are not eligible to register and vote. However, if they are on probation, released on parole, in a halfway house, or under house arrest, they are eligible to register and vote. Additionally, individuals who were ever convicted of a misdemeanor, pretrial detainees, and those released from correctional facilities or halfway houses upon completion of their term of incarceration for a felony conviction are also eligible to register and vote.

If you've missed the deadline to request an absentee ballot and can't get to your polling place, you may be eligible for an Emergency Ballot.

This type of ballot is for emergency situations only, such as an unexpected illness, disability, or last-minute absence from your municipality. You can request an Emergency Absentee Ballot beginning at 5 p.m. the Tuesday before the election. The deadline to submit your Emergency Absentee Ballot Application to your county election board is 8 p.m. on Election Day.

Additionally, if you are unable to pick up or return your emergency ballot, you can authorize a representative to do so on your behalf.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response:
To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29.

If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it.

Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially designated another person to do so on your behalf.

There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status online.

user_query: How can we be sure that the PA election will be fair?
dewey_match: How can we be sure that the PA election will be fair?
response:
In Pennsylvania, measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity, including layers of protection in the commonwealth's voter registration process and the use of voting machines that produce a voter-verifiable paper record.

Pennsylvania counties also conduct two types of post-election analyses: a 2% statistical sample required by state statute, and a statewide risk-limiting audit. Risk-limiting audits are scientifically designed procedures that use statistical methods to confirm election outcomes and to detect possible interference.

You can read more about election security via the Pennsylvania Department of State.

user_query: I moved and did not update my registration
dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response:
If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address.

For more details, you can refer to the “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.

user_query: If I didn't sign up for an absentee ballot but can't get to my polling place, how can I vote?
dewey_match: If I didn't sign up for an absentee ballot but can't get to my polling place, how can I vote?
response:
If you've missed the deadline to request an absentee ballot and can't get to your polling place, you may be eligible for an Emergency Ballot.

This type of ballot is for emergency situations only, such as an unexpected illness, disability, or last-minute absence from your municipality. You can request an Emergency Absentee Ballot beginning at 5 p.m. the Tuesday before the election. The deadline to submit your Emergency Absentee Ballot Application to your county election board is 8 p.m. on Election Day.

Additionally, if you are unable to pick up or return your emergency ballot, you can authorize a representative to do so on your behalf.

If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it.

Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially designated another person to do so on your behalf.

There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status online.

user_query: How do I vote a provisional ballot?
dewey_match: How do I vote a provisional ballot?
response:
If you arrive at a polling place and are told you must use a provisional ballot, election workers will instruct you to fill out a form that includes your personal information and an affidavit, then submit it. Afterward, you'll get a receipt with your provisional ballot identification number.

Provisional ballots are counted after regular ones, and workers conduct extra checks to ensure their voters are eligible. You can find out whether your ballot was counted by entering either your ballot ID number or name and birthdate in the Department of State's provisional ballot search tool.

You can also call 1-877-VOTESPA.

There are a number of reasons why voters need to use provisional ballots. They include situations in which it's unclear whether a voter is eligible to vote in Pennsylvania, if their eligibility in a specific district is uncertain, if they can't show ID and it's their first time at a polling place, or if they received a mail ballot but haven't used or surrendered it.

user_query: What is a provisional ballot and when would I need to use one?
dewey_match: What is a provisional ballot and when would I need to use one?
response: A provisional ballot is used when county election officials need more time to determine a voter's eligibility. You may need to use a provisional ballot if your name is not in the poll book, if you are required to show ID but cannot, if your eligibility is challenged, if there is a special court order related to your registration status, if there is a special court order to extend voting hours, or if you believe you are registered in a political party but your voter record indicates otherwise (for primary elections only). It's a way to ensure your vote is recorded while your eligibility is being determined.

dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response:
If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address.

For more details, you can refer to the “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.

user_query: Who is Tim DeFoor?
dewey_match: Who is Tim DeFoor?
response:
Tim DeFoor is the current auditor general of Pennsylvania, having taken office in January 2021. DeFoor is the first person of color to win a state row office in Pennsylvania and the first Republican to hold the auditor general position since 1997. He is running for reelection in 2024.

In his announcement that he would seek another four years in office, DeFoor said his first term focused on transforming the auditor general’s office in a nonpartisan way, and that his second would center on “ensuring the job gets done.” DeFoor has primarily stuck to the office’s required functions: auditing local pension plans and volunteer firefighters’ relief associations, and making sure county offices and district courts handle state money properly.

user_query: What are David McCormick's top proposals and issues?
dewey_match: What are David McCormick's top proposals and issues?
response:
McCormick’s relationship with China has been a through-line of the campaign. As CEO of Bridgewater, he oversaw investments in China and publicly spoke of “admiration” for China and the promise of U.S. involvement in the nation.

It has earned him criticism from both sides of the political aisle. But he argues his hedge fund experience qualifies him to navigate the complex U.S.-China relationship.

On his campaign website, McCormick says he opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest, or to protect the life of a parent. He also says he doesn’t support a federal ban.

Another issue that McCormick has highlighted is shale gas fracking, an extraction process that has been used in Pennsylvania for two decades.

He claims both Harris and Casey want to ban fracking and has said fracking is “great for the environment.” Harris did support a fracking ban when she ran for president in 2020, but says she no longer does. Casey never has.

He has also blamed fentanyl proliferation on Democratic border policies, though experts say the synthetic opioid primarily enters the U.S. through legal ports of entry. And in ads he has tied inflation to Democratic spending while touting himself as a job creator — though on that claim, he has also faced criticism for layoffs he oversaw in his corporate roles.

user_query: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
response:
The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican.

The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds.

Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings.

Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’”

Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice.

user_query: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response:
If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address.

For more details, you can refer to the “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.

user_query: Who is Stacy Garrity?
dewey_match: Who is Stacy Garrity?
response:
Stacy Garrity, a Republican, is Pennsylvania's state treasurer. She is a retired U.S. Army Reserve colonel and a graduate of Bloomsburg University of Pennsylvania. She was deployed three times, earning two Bronze Stars and the Legion of Merit award. Following her military service, Garrity worked at Global Tungsten & Powders as vice president of government affairs and industry liaison.

Garrity was elected Pennsylvania state treasurer in 2020 and is running for reelection. In her bid for a second four-year term, she has focused on transparency, pledged to return unclaimed property, and said she wants to reduce wasteful state spending.

user_query: What are some major issues that Pennsylvania legislators have voted on recently?
dewey_match: What are some major issues that Pennsylvania legislators have voted on recently?
response:
Major initiatives considered by the state House over the past year include:

-The 2023 and 2024 state budget deal.

-The vote that made state Rep. Mark Rozzi (D., Berks) speaker of the Pennsylvania House.

-A proposed constitutional amendment that would give survivors of childhood sexual abuse a two-year window to file lawsuits.

-Bills that would raise the minimum wage to $12 or $15 an hour.

-A measure that would add LGBTQ nondiscrimination protections to the state’s civil rights law, covering employment, housing, and schooling.

Major initiatives considered by the state Senate over the past year include:

-The 2023 and 2024 state budget deal.

-A proposed omnibus constitutional amendment that would give survivors of childhood sexual abuse a two-year window to file lawsuits, require people to show ID every time they vote, and make it easier for the legislature to override regulations.

-A law that would allow police to pull a driver over solely for using their phone

-A law that establishes a state regulatory regime for carbon capture and storage.

-A law that requires electric vehicle owners to pay a $200 fee starting in 2025 and increasing afterward to the state Department of Transportation for highway funding.

user_query: What are the main differences between Erin McClelland and Stacy Garrity?
dewey_match: What are the main differences between Erin McClelland and Stacy Garrity?
response:
The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican.

The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds.

Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings.

Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’”

Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice.

Take our PA treasurer candidate quiz to see which major party candidate for Pennsylvania treasurer most closely aligns with what matters to you.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response:
To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29.

If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it.

Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially designated another person to do so on your behalf.

There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status online.

user_query: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
dewey_match: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
response: Poll watchers must remain outside the enclosed space of the polling place and can be present from the time election officers meet prior to the opening of the polls until the counting of votes is complete. They may inspect certain voter lists when no voters are present. However, poll watchers cannot engage in electioneering, make challenges based on irrelevant characteristics, or engage in voter intimidation. The Judge of Elections has the duty to address challenges made by poll watchers and maintain order in the polling place according to Pennsylvania law.

user_query: how can i become a poll watcher or observer
dewey_match: How do you become a poll watcher?
response:
Poll watchers are appointed by a candidate or a political party represented on the ballot, and assigned to specific precincts.

Watchers must be certified by their county’s board of elections before Election Day and must keep that certification on hand during voting. To obtain certification, county election directors must verify that the volunteer is registered to vote in the county that they wish to observe.

user_query: How do I use a ballot dropoff box?
dewey_match: How do I use a ballot dropoff box?
response:
To use a ballot drop off box in Pennsylvania, simply seal your completed mail-in or absentee ballot in the provided secrecy envelope, then place it in the outer envelope. Sign and date the outer envelope as instructed.

After preparing your ballot, locate an official dropbox in your county. Deposit your ballot in the drop box before the 8 p.m. Election Day deadline. Remember that you must return your own ballot, unless you have a disability and have designated someone in writing to deliver it. For additional information, you can visit vote.pa.gov for the Pennsylvania Department of State's rules for mail ballots.

response: Yes, a person registered as an independent can still vote in elections, but in Pennsylvania there is an exception when it comes to primary elections. Voters who are registered without a political affiliation or with a third party can still participate in statewide referenda, local ballot initiatives, and special elections that coincide with the primaries.

user_query: What are the main differences between Erin McClelland and Stacy Garrity?
dewey_match: What are the main differences between Erin McClelland and Stacy Garrity?
response: The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican. The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds. Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings. Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’” Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice. user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
dewey_match: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
response: Poll watchers must remain outside the enclosed space of the polling place and can be present from the time election officers meet prior to the opening of the polls until the counting of votes is complete. They may inspect certain voter lists when no voters are present. However, poll watchers cannot engage in electioneering, make challenges based on irrelevant characteristics, or engage in voter intimidation. The Judge of Elections has the duty to address challenges made by poll watchers and maintain order in the polling place according to Pennsylvania law.

user_query: How do I use a ballot dropoff box?
dewey_match: How do I use a ballot dropoff box?
response: To use a ballot drop off box in Pennsylvania, simply seal your completed mail-in or "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" absentee ballot in the provided secrecy envelope, then place it in the outer envelope. Sign and date the outer envelope as instructed. After preparing your ballot, locate an official dropbox in your county. Deposit your ballot in the drop box before the 8 p.m. Election Day deadline. Remember that you must return your own ballot, unless you have a disability and have designated someone in writing to deliver it. For additional information, you can visit "https://vote.pa.gov" vote.pa.gov for the Pennsylvania Department of State's rules for mail ballots.

user_query: I moved from a different county but didn’t change my registration.
dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response: If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address. For more details, you can refer to the "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-registration/update-my-registration.html" “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: When is the deadline for mail ballots?
dewey_match: When is the deadline for mail ballots?
response: The deadline to apply for a mail ballot was Oct. 29. Your local county election board must receive your application by  5 p.m. on this date. The deadline to return your filled out mail ballot is 8 p.m. on Election Day, which is Tuesday, November 5.

response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

response: You can apply for a mail ballot in Pennsylvania "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online at the Department of State's website, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Applications to vote by mail in the 2024 general election must be received by your county election office by 5 p.m. on Oct. 29. You must provide proper identification to apply for a mail ballot. Acceptable options include a valid Pennsylvania driver’s license or a valid PennDOT ID card, or the last four digits of a Social Security number. You can also use a photo employee ID from an accredited Pennsylvania public or private institution, like a college or university. For a full list of approved forms of identification, please refer to the "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Voting-in-PA/Pages/Mail-and-Absentee-Ballot.aspx" Department of State's website. You can either apply for a one-time mail ballot or to be added to the annual request list, which means you’ll get an application each year. user_query: Can felons vote in PA elections?
dewey_match: Can felons vote in PA elections?
response: Yes, individuals with "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/your-rights-and-the-law/criminal-status-and-voting.html" felony convictions in Pennsylvania can register and vote "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Register-to-Vote/Pages/Convicted-Felon,-Misdemeanant-or-Pretrial-Detainee.aspx" if they meet certain criteria. If they are currently confined in a penal institution for a felony conviction and will not be released until after the next election, they are not eligible to register and vote. However, if they are on probation, released on parole, in a halfway house, or under house arrest, they are eligible to register and vote. Additionally, individuals who were ever convicted of a misdemeanor, pretrial detainees, and those released from correctional facilities or halfway houses upon completion of their term of incarceration for a felony conviction are also eligible to register and vote.
Notes: Suggestions: 1) swap "penal institution" to "correctional facility" (to match Dept. of State language. 2) I don't think second mention of halfway houses (red) is needed here.

user_query: How can I feel confident that only citizens are able to vote in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: How can I feel confident that only citizens are able to vote in Pennsylvania?
response: In Pennsylvania, the voter registration process requires individuals to provide proof of United States citizenship. When registering to vote, applicants must affirm their U.S. citizenship under penalty of perjury. Additionally, election officials are responsible for verifying the authenticity of voter registration information.
Notes: Yes, but indirectly-- driver's license, PennDotID, and social security all require citizenship in PA and those are the document options for registration. Must be a citizen to register to vote.

user_query: What is being done by the state to counter voter suppression?
dewey_match: What is being done by the state to counter voter suppression?
response: State and federal laws prohibit discriminatory conduct and voter intimidation, with penalties for those who violate these laws. Officials urge voters to report instances of voter intimidation to their county board of elections, the district attorney, and the Department of State at 1-877-VOTESPA. These entities are responsible for investigating and prosecuting any alleged violations of the Election Code, with the Office of Attorney General also having authority to address voter intimidation.
Notes: Doesn't really answer question about voter suppression (which can be done by state itself + its rules) but that may be beyond the scope

user_query: What measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity?
dewey_match: What measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity?
response:
In Pennsylvania, measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity, including layers of protection in the commonwealth's voter registration process and the use of voting machines that produce a voter-verifiable paper record.

Pennsylvania counties also conduct two types of post-election analyses: a 2% statistical sample required by state statute, and a statewide risk-limiting audit. Risk-limiting audits are scientifically designed procedures that use statistical methods to confirm election outcomes and to detect possible interference.

You can read more about counties' efforts to secure voter registration, voting, and vote tallying at vote.pa.gov

user_query: What safeguards are in place to prevent fraud in Pennsylvania elections?
dewey_match: What safeguards are in place to prevent fraud in Pennsylvania elections?
response: Pennsylvania has several safeguards in place to prevent election fraud. The state verifies the identity of "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot applicants by cross-referencing their information with databases like the driver’s license database. Additionally, all voting machines in Pennsylvania produce paper ballots that can be audited, allowing officials to verify the accuracy of the results. These measures, along with a decentralized election administration system and local oversight, work together to ensure the integrity of the electoral process in the state.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response: If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address. For more details, you can refer to the "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-registration/update-my-registration.html" “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.

user_query: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
response: The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican. The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds. Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings. Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a  “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’” Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice. Take our "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/10/pennsylvania-election-2024-treasurer-candidates-quiz/" PA treasurer candidate quiz to see which major party candidate for Pennsylvania treasurer most closely aligns with what matters to you.

user_query: If I received a mail in ballot, can I still vote in person?
dewey_match: If I received a mail in ballot, can I still vote in person?
response: If you have a mail ballot but decide not to use it, you can still vote in person at your local polling place on Election Day. Bring all your mail ballot components, including the envelopes, to your polling place and turn them over to poll workers. You’ll be required to sign a form declaring that you haven’t voted by mail. After that, you should be allowed to vote at the polling place.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: Why does it take time to count and produce unofficial election results in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: Why does it take time to count and produce unofficial election results in Pennsylvania?
response: It takes time to count and produce unofficial election results in Pennsylvania due to the logistical complexities of processing mail-in ballots and ensuring accuracy and security in the tabulation process. The state's significant expansion of mail voting, combined with the absence of pre-canvassing, has contributed to delays in producing unofficial results. Despite efforts to address ballot-counting kinks, local election officials prioritize accuracy and security above all else, which may result in some races' results not being known on election night. It's essential to rely on trusted sources for accurate election-related information.

user_query: What are Bob Casey's top proposals and issues?
dewey_match: What are Bob Casey's top proposals and issues?
response: Casey is a staunch supporter of the Affordable Care Act, chaired the U.S. Senate’s special committee on aging (where he "https://www.inquirer.com/health/nursing-home-survey-senate-aging-committee-bob-casey-20230622.html" continued his auditor general-era work on nursing home oversight), and has steadily moved left on a host of his more conservative positions — in particular, gun control and abortion. Like his father, Casey opposed abortion access when he first entered the U.S. Senate. In recent years, however, he has become a defender of abortion access and, "https://apnews.com/article/abortion-pennsylvania-senate-casey-mccormick-6f67b60b0e81b2631f02ab6cbb629678" as the Associated Press has written, has argued that his longtime identity as a “pro-life Democrat” and past votes for abortion restrictions never meant he supported total bans. Casey has vowed to be tough on China, saying he supports keeping jobs in Pennsylvania and promoting his lead sponsorship of "https://www.casey.senate.gov/news/releases/casey-cornyn-bill-to-screen-us-investment-in-china-overwhelmingly-passes-senate-2023" a national security bill that would require screening of American companies’ investments in several key tech sectors in “countries of concern,” including China. He has walked a fine line on energy and the environment. He "https://www.casey.senate.gov/news/releases/casey-fetterman-release-statement-on-biden-administration-pause-on-liquefied-natural-gas-exports" criticized the Biden administration’s pause on approving liquefied natural gas exports to certain countries, for instance, but also vocally supported the administration’s sweeping spending bills on environmental infrastructure and maintains "https://scorecard.lcv.org/moc/bob-casey" a 94% lifetime approval score from the League of Conservation Voters. In ads, he has highlighted his efforts to "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KOhD6TMst-U" keep steel production in the U.S. and to "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WKRru4mFz6A" produce microchips domestically instead of in China. He has also focused on consumer protection, noting that he’s a sponsor of the proposed Price Gouging Prevention Act, and saying "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7owbZQs-J1g" in an ad that he wants to “roll back [companies’] huge corporate tax breaks, putting money in your pocket instead.”
Notes: Notes: 1) "chaired" --> "chairs" (per here, here) 2) "...Casey opposed abortion access when he first entered the U.S. Senate." --> "Casey once opposed abortion access." (As recently as 2018 he voted to limit abortion access, and he has been in the Senate since 2007!)

response: You have a couple of options. First, you can call your county election office, or stop by in person, and request a replacement ballot. You can then fill out and return that ballot. Find contact information for your county election office by visiting "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Resources/Pages/Contact-Your-Election-Officials.aspx" this link. If you decide to seek a replacement ballot, it's important that you do this by the deadline to request a mail ballot which is 5 p.m. on Oct. 29. You can also go in person to your polling place on Election Day and explain that you requested a mail ballot but didn't receive it. A worker will instruct you on voting by provisional ballot. This is a type of ballot subjected to extra scrutiny before being counted to ensure the voter is eligible and not voting twice.

Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.
