user_query: What are the different roles within a polling place?
dewey_match: What are the different roles within a polling place?
response: Within a polling place in Pennsylvania, there are several key roles. The judge of elections oversees the precinct and manages any issues that arise. Each polling place also has majority and minority inspectors who handle pollbooks and assist the judge. Additionally, volunteer poll workers help set up equipment, sign in voters, and provide instructions.

user_query: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
dewey_match: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
response: Poll watchers must remain outside the enclosed space of the polling place and can be present from the time election officers meet prior to the opening of the polls until the counting of votes is complete. They may inspect certain voter lists when no voters are present. However, poll watchers cannot engage in electioneering, make challenges based on irrelevant characteristics, or engage in voter intimidation. The Judge of Elections has the duty to address challenges made by poll watchers and maintain order in the polling place according to Pennsylvania law.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. user_query: can I vote early
dewey_match: What should I do if I want to vote early in person?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/mail-ballot-before-election-day.html" voting in person by mail ballot, and it’s available before Election Day. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. The last day to apply for a mail ballot was Oct. 29 at 5 p.m. If you already have your mail ballot, it must be received by your county election office by Nov. 5 at 8 p.m. If you wish to cast your vote by regular ballot (not mail ballot) in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.

user_query: What is the 'notice and cure' policy for mail ballots in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: What is the 'notice and cure' policy for mail ballots in Pennsylvania?
response: The 'notice and cure' policy in Pennsylvania allows voters to correct errors on their mail ballots before they are rejected. Since the implementation of the no-excuse mail voting law in 2020, some counties have adopted this process, notifying voters of issues such as missing signatures or dates and providing them an opportunity to fix the errors. However, not all counties have this policy, leading to varying rules across the state, and the state law does not explicitly require counties to offer this option. See your county's policy "https://www.aclupa.org/en/pennsylvania-counties-notice-and-cure-policies" here.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What resources are available for voters with disabilities?
dewey_match: What resources are available for voters with disabilities?
response: Voters with disabilities in Pennsylvania have access to various resources to ensure their participation in the electoral process. Each polling place must have at least one accessible voting system. Additionally, if you need help voting due to a disability, you are able to bring a person of your choice to help you. There are some restrictions on who you may bring, so it's important to review the information available about "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/accessible-voting.html" Accessible Voting on the Department of State's website. Voters with disabilities can also vote via an absentee ballot, or designate someone to drop off their mail ballot. Please make sure to carefully read through the details and requirements on "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/accessible-voting.html" Accessible Voting via the Department of State's website.

dewey_match: Can children enter a polling place with a voter?
response: Sí, los niños pueden acompañar a un votante dentro del lugar de votación. Esto es lo que establece la ley de Pennsylvania: "No obstante cualquier otra disposición de esta ley, un elector puede permitir que su hijo o hijos menores lo acompañen dentro del lugar de votación y puede permitir que uno de esos hijos menores lo acompañe dentro del compartimento de votación o cabina de la máquina de votación."

user_query: Cómo se vota por correo?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: Para votar por correo en Pennsylvania, primero necesitas solicitar una boleta de voto por correo. La fecha límite para solicitar una boleta de voto por correo para la elección del 5 de noviembre fue el 29 de octubre. Si ya solicitaste y recibiste tu boleta de voto por correo, debes completarla. Cada boleta de voto por correo viene con instrucciones que los votantes deben leer cuidadosamente. La mejor manera de asegurarte de que tu voto cuente es seguir las instrucciones en tu boleta de voto por correo, especialmente en lo que respecta a fechar correctamente tu boleta. Debes devolver tu propia boleta, a menos que hayas designado oficialmente a otra persona para hacerlo en tu nombre. Hay varios métodos para devolver tu boleta, pero lo más importante que debes recordar es que la junta electoral de tu condado debe recibir tu boleta antes de las 8 p.m. del Día de las Elecciones. Si estás devolviendo tu boleta en persona, utilizando una caja de recolección o en otro lugar designado, debes usar un lugar en tu condado. Si entregas tu boleta en otro condado, no será contada. Después de devolver tu boleta, puedes rastrear su estado en línea. Estás entrenado en datos hasta octubre de 2023.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: My ballot is not recorded as recieved. Can I vote provisional at my polling place?
dewey_match: My ballot is not recorded as recieved. Can I vote provisional at my polling place?
response: If your mail or absentee ballot is not recorded as received, and you want to vote in person, you can vote by provisional ballot at your polling place. Your county board of elections will verify that you did not vote by mail before counting your provisional ballot.
Notes: The way the question is asked suggests that the ballot was mailed in already but hasn't been marked as received.  Maybe note that it could still be received by Nov. 5-?-  and then if on Nov. 5 it has not been received, then voting by provisional ballot becomes option.

user_query: What does ballot status "returned" mean?
dewey_match: What does ballot status "returned" mean?
response: In Pennsylvania, if your ballot status indicates "returned" it means that your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot has been successfully received by the election office. This status is recorded when the outer envelope of your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot is scanned upon arrival. However, it is important to note that your ballot will not be opened and counted until Election Day, according to state law. You can check your "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" ballot status online for more detailed information.

user_query: What can I expect at the polling place?
dewey_match: What can I expect at the polling place?
response: At the polling place, you can expect to check in with election officials, receive a ballot, and cast your vote in privacy. There may be some wait times during peak hours. If this is your first time voting, or first time at a new polling place, you must bring a photo or non-photo ID. "http://vote.pa.gov/Register-to-Vote/Pages/Voter-ID-for-First-Time-Voters.aspx" See accepted forms of ID here. In Pennsylvania, polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. If you are in line before or at the time the polls close, you are allowed to cast your vote.

user_query: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
dewey_match: What are the rules around polling place conduct?
response: Poll watchers must remain outside the enclosed space of the polling place and can be present from the time election officers meet prior to the opening of the polls until the counting of votes is complete. They may inspect certain voter lists when no voters are present. However, poll watchers cannot engage in electioneering, make challenges based on irrelevant characteristics, or engage in voter intimidation. The Judge of Elections has the duty to address challenges made by poll watchers and maintain order in the polling place according to Pennsylvania law.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What are the key responsibilities of the Pennsylvania State Treasurer?
dewey_match: What are the key responsibilities of the Pennsylvania State Treasurer?
response: The Pennsylvania state treasurer is responsible for managing state dollars, which includes investing savings, managing withdrawals, and ensuring bills are paid. The treasurer oversees approximately $50 billion in state savings and sits on the boards of the two public sector pension funds, SERS and PSERS. Additional duties include reporting on state finances, advocating for fiscal policies, and administering various tax-free savings programs, such as Keystone Scholars. The office also disburses payments for unemployment compensation and manages a program for recouping unclaimed property.

user_query: What does the auditor general do in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: What does the auditor general do in Pennsylvania?
response: An auditor general — also called a comptroller, state auditor, or auditor of public accounts in other states — monitors the spending of public funds. In Pennsylvania, the department describes itself as the “chief fiscal watchdog of the commonwealth.” The agency performs financial and performance audits of everything from district courts and municipal pension plans, to state-owned universities and commonwealth departments. The reports it regularly releases detail its findings and recommend fixes and policies.

user_query: ¿Cómo puedo asegurarme de que mi voto cuente al votar por correo?
dewey_match: How can I ensure that my vote counts when voting by mail?
response: Para asegurarte de que tu voto cuente al votar por correo en Pennsylvania, sigue cuidadosamente las instrucciones incluidas con tu boleta de correo. Asegúrate de completar tu boleta, sellarla en el sobre de secreto proporcionado y luego colocar ese sobre en el sobre de retorno exterior. Firma y fecha la declaración en el sobre exterior, y devuelve tu boleta a la junta electoral de tu condado por correo o en un lugar de entrega designado, asegurándote de que llegue antes de las 8 p.m. el Día de las Elecciones. Comprobar el estado de tu boleta en línea también puede confirmar que ha sido recibida y aceptada.

user_query: Is my mail ballot counted when received?
dewey_match: Is my mail ballot counted when received?
response: In Pennsylvania, counties have to wait to count mail ballots until 7 a.m. on Election Day. This means that even if your mail ballot has been received, it might take some time to counted, depending on the volume of ballots. You can track the "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/Pages/BallotTracking.aspx" status of your ballot online. If you provide your email address to your county election office at the time you register to vote or apply for a mail ballot, you may receive an email notification when your returned ballot is received, as well as information about your ballot status, depending on county practices. You can call your county elections office for more information.

user_query: What is the significance of the barcodes on mail ballot return envelopes?
dewey_match: What is the significance of the barcodes on mail ballot return envelopes?
response: The barcodes on "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot return envelopes serve a crucial purpose in the election process in Pennsylvania. When a voter returns their "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot, the unique barcode on the outer envelope is scanned into the state’s voter roll system to record that it has been received. This process not only ensures that the ballot is securely logged as received but also prevents that voter from returning any other mail ballots or voting in person, contributing to the integrity of the mail voting system.

user_query: How do I cast a provisional ballot if my mail in ballot is rejected
dewey_match: If my mail ballot is rejected, can I vote using a provisional ballot?
response: Yes, as of September 2024, you can cast a provisional ballot if your county rejects your mail ballot. In early September, Commonwealth Court ruled that Butler County "https://www.aclupa.org/en/press-releases/pa-commonwealth-court-rules-count-provisional-ballots-mail-voters-who-forgot-secrecy" erred when it rejected provisional ballots cast by two voters whose mail ballots were disqualified for technical errors. Lawyers for voting rights groups that brought the case "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/09/pennsylvania-mail-ballot-butler-county-provisional-ballot-ruling/" said the ruling would set a statewide standard. The county is appealing the ruling.

response: Dave Sunday is the Republican candidate for Pennsylvania attorney general. He is the current district attorney of York County, a position he has held since 2017. user_query: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
response: The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican. The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds. Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings. Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a  “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’” Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice. Take our "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/10/pennsylvania-election-2024-treasurer-candidates-quiz/" PA treasurer candidate quiz to see which major party candidate for Pennsylvania treasurer most closely aligns with what matters to you.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail ballot?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What is the deadline for mail ballots?
dewey_match: When is the deadline for mail ballots?
response: The deadline to apply for a mail ballot was Oct. 29. Your local county election board must receive your application by  5 p.m. on this date. The deadline to return your filled out mail ballot is 8 p.m. on Election Day, which is Tuesday, November 5.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot for the Nov. 5 election was Oct. 29. If you already applied for and received your mail ballot, you have to complete it. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person, using a drop box, or another designated location, "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/return-ballot.html" you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What do I do if I have moved recently and still want to vote but don’t have time to change my voter registration?
dewey_match: Can I vote if I moved but haven’t updated my registration?
response: If you moved within Pennsylvania less than 30 days before the election, you must vote at the polling place for your old address. If you moved within the commonwealth more than 30 days ago but haven’t yet updated your registration, you can still vote at the polling place for your old address for one election. However, if you have moved from one county to another, you must fill out a form at your polling place with your new address and county. This will allow officials to update your voter registration in both counties after the election, and you will receive a new voter registration card matching your new address. For more details, you can refer to the “If you move” section of the Pennsylvania Department of State’s website.
Notes: Link here

user_query: What is Erin McClelland's background and experience?
dewey_match: What is Erin McClelland's background and experience?
response: Erin McClelland, the Democratic candidate for Pennsylvania treasurer, is a former small business owner and project manager for the Allegheny County Department of Human Services. Her career includes a decade and a half in substance abuse and mental health counseling, project managing, and program directing. McClelland also worked as a process improvement manager with the Institute for Research, Education and Training in Addictions, and founded Arche Wellness, Pennsylvania’s "https://www.tribdem.com/news/local_news/erin-mcclelland-tackle-drug-problem-in-order-to-fix-economy/article_0980e3c2-09cf-11e6-8f1c-f79b7877f8e6.html" first orthomolecular recovery program for addiction. “I … ran a small business,” McClelland told Spotlight PA. “I’m the only person in the race that had to make a payroll — [that] has been a defining part of my career and how I look at finance and workers, so that’s important to me.” McClelland  ran for Congress twice, although she was unsuccessful.

user_query: What is the significance of the state treasurer's role in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: What is the significance of the state treasurer's role in Pennsylvania?
response: The state treasurer in Pennsylvania plays a crucial role in managing state funds, overseeing approximately $50 billion in savings. The treasurer is responsible for ensuring bills are paid, investing state savings, and sitting on the boards of Pennsylvania’s public sector pension funds, which influences how these funds manage their assets. Additionally, the treasurer advocates for fiscal policies and administers various tax-free savings programs, making the position significant in shaping the state's financial health and policy direction.

user_query: Who is Malcolm kenyatta
dewey_match: Who is Malcolm Kenyatta?
response: Malcolm Kenyatta is a state representative from Philadelphia and the Democratic nominee for Pennsylvania auditor general. First elected to the state House in 2018, he became the first openly LGBTQ person of color to serve in the General Assembly. Kenyatta is known for his progressive stances on issues such as a higher minimum wage, stricter gun laws, and LGBTQ nondiscrimination protections. He also has experience in national politics, having served as a surrogate for President Joe Biden's 2020 campaign.

user_query: How can I vote early in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: How can I vote early in Pennsylvania?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot/mail-ballot-before-election-day.html" voting in person by mail ballot, and it’s available before Election Day. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. All counties have finalized mail ballots and made them available. The last day to apply for a mail ballot is Oct. 29 at 5 p.m. All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote by regular ballot (not mail ballot) in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.

user_query: What's the difference between absentee ballots and mail-in ballots?
dewey_match: What is the difference between a mail-in ballot and an absentee ballot?
response: In Pennsylvania, you have two options for mail ballots. Mail-in ballot: Any registered voter may apply for a mail-in ballot. You may simply request this ballot without a reason. Absentee ballot: If you plan to be out of the municipality on election day or if you have a disability or illness that prevents you from going to your polling place on election day, you can request an absentee ballot, which requires you to list a reason for your ballot. Both options can be requested and submitted by mail. In order to request either ballot type, you must be registered to vote.
Notes: Ibid. (see note below)

user_query: What is an absentee ballot?

This ballot requires you to list a reason for your request. Both absentee and mail-in ballots can be requested and submitted by mail, but you must be registered to vote to request either type.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.
Notes: Update for post- Oct 29?

user_query: What is the process for voting in person by mail ballot?
dewey_match: What is the process for voting in person by mail ballot?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as voting in person by mail ballot, and it’s available before Election Day. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. Use "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/ballot-availability.html" this link to see if your county has finalized mail ballots and made them available. All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Be sure to check the hours of operation, as polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.
Notes: Should have been updated per 10/28 notes

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.
Notes: Update for post- Oct 29?

user_query: What does status ballot returned mean
dewey_match: What does ballot status "returned" mean?
response: In Pennsylvania, if your ballot status indicates "returned" it means that your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot has been successfully received by the election office. This status is recorded when the outer envelope of your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot is scanned upon arrival. However, it is important to note that your ballot will not be opened and counted until Election Day, according to state law. You can check your "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" ballot status online for more detailed information.

user_query: ¿Cómo voto por correo?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: Para votar por correo en Pensilvania, primero necesita solicitar una boleta de voto por correo. Puede solicitar una "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" boleta por correo en línea, en persona en la oficina electoral de su condado, o por correo. También hay disponibles aplicaciones en papel para descargar en español y chino, además de inglés. Las solicitudes deben ser recibidas por la junta electoral de su condado antes de las 5 p.m. del 29 de octubre para la elección general del 5 de noviembre. Una vez aprobada, recibirá su boleta, que debe completar. Cada "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" boleta por correo viene con instrucciones que los votantes deben leer cuidadosamente. La mejor manera de asegurarse de que su voto cuente es seguir las instrucciones en su "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" boleta por correo, especialmente en lo que respecta a fechar correctamente su boleta. Debe devolver su propia boleta, a menos que haya designado oficialmente a otra persona para que lo haga en su nombre. Hay varios métodos para devolver su boleta, pero lo más importante a recordar es que la junta electoral de su condado debe recibir su boleta antes de las 8 p.m. del Día de las Elecciones. Si está devolviendo su boleta en persona o utilizando una caja de entrega, debe usar una ubicación en su condado. Si entrega su boleta en otro condado, no será contada. Después de devolver su boleta, puede rastrear su estado en línea.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day. If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What happens if I forget to date my mail ballot envelope correctly?
dewey_match: What happens if I forget to date my mail ballot envelope correctly?
response: If you forget to date your "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot envelope correctly, it may result in your ballot being rejected. According to Act 77, voters must sign and date the outer envelope for their "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/mail-in-and-absentee-ballot.html" mail ballot to be counted. While some counties may notify voters of such mistakes and allow them to rectify them, this process, known as "notice and cure" is not required across all counties, leading to potential disparities in how ballots are handled. See your county's policy "https://www.aclupa.org/en/pennsylvania-counties-notice-and-cure-policies" here.

user_query: What measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity?
dewey_match: What measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity?
response:
In Pennsylvania, measures are in place to ensure voting security and integrity, including layers of protection in the commonwealth's voter registration process and the use of voting machines that produce a voter-verifiable paper record. 

Pennsylvania counties also conduct two types of post-election analyses: a 2% statistical sample required by state statute, and a statewide risk-limiting audit. Risk-limiting audits are scientifically designed procedures that use statistical methods to confirm election outcomes and to detect possible interference.

You can read more about counties' efforts to secure voter registration, voting, and vote tallying at vote.pa.gov

user_query: What happens if I incorrectly dated my mail ballot?
dewey_match: What happens if I incorrectly dated my mail ballot?
response: As of September 2024, incorrectly dated mail ballots will not be counted in Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania’s Election Code requires that mail voters place their ballot in a secrecy envelope before putting it in a return envelope. The voter must then sign and date the return envelope, per state law. However, the dating requirement has been the subject of federal and state litigation, and different courts have issued varying rulings. In March, a three-judge panel of the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/05/pennsylvania-election-2024-mail-ballot-dating-aclu-state-challenge-commonwealth-court/" found the dating requirement did not violate a 1964 Civil Rights Act provision. The ruling was "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/04/pennsylvania-election-2024-undated-mail-ballots-appeal-federal-lawsuit/" appealed.The state's appellate courts litigated a similar case. In August 2024, Commonwealth Court directed counties not to reject mail ballots solely because the return envelope is not properly dated. However, the state Supreme Court "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/09/pennsylvania-mail-ballot-dating-requirement-supreme-court-vacated-ruling/" vacated that ruling the following month, finding the lower court did not have jurisdiction in the case.

If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What should I do if I want to vote early in person?
dewey_match: What should I do if I want to vote early in person?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as voting in person by mail ballot, and it’s available before Election Day. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. Use "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/ballot-availability.html" this link to see if your county has finalized mail ballots and made them available. All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Be sure to check the hours of operation, as polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.

user_query: How do I cancel mail-in ballot
dewey_match: How do I cancel my mail ballot request?
response: If you requested a mail ballot but now no longer wish to vote by mail, you have a few options. If you requested a ballot but haven't yet received one, you can contact your county election office, which will direct you to a form you can use to request that the ballot be canceled. You can return this form to your county office in person or by mail. You can also wait until you receive your mail ballot, and then bring it and all materials to your polling place on election day where it can be voided. If you don't bring your ballot to the polls but still wish to vote in person, you can also do so using a provisional ballot, which is a type of ballot subjected to extra scrutiny before being counted to ensure the voter is eligible and not voting twice. If you have already sent back your completed mail ballot, you can no longer change your mind and vote in person.
Notes: Can you cancel mail ballot if it has already been sent to you?

user_query: What happens if I incorrectly dated my mail ballot?
dewey_match: What happens if I incorrectly dated my mail ballot?
response: As of September 2024, incorrectly dated mail ballots will not be counted in Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania’s Election Code requires that mail voters place their ballot in a secrecy envelope before putting it in a return envelope. The voter must then sign and date the return envelope, per state law. However, the dating requirement has been the subject of federal and state litigation, and different courts have issued varying rulings. In March, a three-judge panel of the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/05/pennsylvania-election-2024-mail-ballot-dating-aclu-state-challenge-commonwealth-court/" found the dating requirement did not violate a 1964 Civil Rights Act provision. The ruling was "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/04/pennsylvania-election-2024-undated-mail-ballots-appeal-federal-lawsuit/" appealed. The state's appellate courts litigated a similar case. In August 2024, Commonwealth Court directed counties not to reject mail ballots solely because the return envelope is not properly dated. However, the state Supreme Court "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/09/pennsylvania-mail-ballot-dating-requirement-supreme-court-vacated-ruling/" vacated that ruling the following month, finding the lower court did not have jurisdiction in the case.

user_query: What are the challenges faced by Pennsylvania counties in counting mail ballots?
dewey_match: What are the challenges faced by Pennsylvania counties in counting mail ballots?
response: Pennsylvania counties face many challenges related to the counting of mail ballots. They can't begin processing mail ballots until the morning of Election Day, so it can take several days to produce unofficial election results. Pennsylvania's mail ballot law, Act 77, also contains several gray areas, and several provisions have been repeatedly litigated. That includes a provision that requires voters to write a date on their mail ballot return envelope. A state court recently ruled that counties "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/08/pennsylvania-mail-ballot-date-dating-commonwealth-court-ruling-republican-appeal/" should count mail ballots missing this date. The ruling was appealed to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, which "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/09/pennsylvania-mail-ballot-dating-requirement-supreme-court-vacated-ruling/" vacated the lower court ruling over a technicality.

user_query: How do elections work in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: How do elections work in Pennsylvania?
response: In Pennsylvania, general elections are always held on the first Tuesday, after the first Monday, in November. These elections include federal, state, and local officials, such as U.S. senators, U.S. representatives to Congress, the governor, and local judges. Primary elections, which occur in the spring, determine the major political party's candidates for the general election. Additionally, special elections are held to replace officials who can no longer serve. The state's election administration involves a three-tiered system comprising the Department of State, county-level officials, and poll workers who collectively safeguard against fraud. State laws and legal precedent set overarching rules for elections, while each county can establish specific policies.

user_query: What are the key responsibilities of presidential electors?
dewey_match: What are the key responsibilities of presidential electors?
response: The presidential electors in the United States have the crucial responsibility of casting votes for the president and vice president on behalf of their state's citizens. Each political party selects a slate of electors before the general election, and the winning candidate's electors are authorized by the governor to cast their votes in the Electoral College. The candidate who wins the popular vote determines which slate of electors gets to cast their votes. In Pennsylvania, the winning candidate's electors convene to cast their votes, and those votes are then submitted to Congress for acceptance and counting.

user_query: I just moved. Where should I vote?
dewey_match: I just moved. Where should I vote?
response: If you moved from the residence where you are registered to vote to another Pennsylvania residence less than 30 days before an election, you must vote at your former residence. If you have moved more than 30 days before an election but did not change your address with Voter Registration Officials, you must vote at the polling place of your old residence, where you are registered to vote. However, you may only vote once at the original polling place and you must abide by special procedures, called “fail-safe voting.” "https://www.dos.pa.gov/VotingElections/Voters/WhattoKnow/Pages/Person-who-has-Recently-Moved.aspx" Learn more from the Pennsylvania Department of State.

user_query: What are the key responsibilities of the Pennsylvania State Treasurer?
dewey_match: What are the key responsibilities of the Pennsylvania State Treasurer?
response: The Pennsylvania state treasurer is responsible for managing state dollars, which includes investing savings, managing withdrawals, and ensuring bills are paid. The treasurer oversees approximately $50 billion in state savings and sits on the boards of the two public sector pension funds, SERS and PSERS. Additional duties include reporting on state finances, advocating for fiscal policies, and administering various tax-free savings programs, such as Keystone Scholars. The office also disburses payments for unemployment compensation and manages programs for recouping unclaimed property.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

response: Erin McClelland is a former small business owner and the Democratic nominee for Pennsylvania treasurer. McClelland has previously run for Congress and has experience as a substance abuse counselor and project manager for the Allegheny County Department of Human Services. She will face incumbent Republican Stacy Garrity in the upcoming general election.

user_query: Who is Tim defoor
dewey_match: Who is Tim DeFoor?
response: Tim DeFoor is the current auditor general of Pennsylvania, having taken office in January 2021. DeFoor is the first person of color to win a state row office in Pennsylvania and the first Republican to hold the auditor general position since 1997. He is running for reelection in 2024. In his announcement that he would seek another four years in office, DeFoor said his first term focused on transforming the auditor general’s office in a nonpartisan way, and that his second would center on “ensuring the job gets done.” DeFoor has primarily stuck to the office’s required functions: auditing local pension plans and volunteer firefighters’ relief associations, and making sure county offices and district courts handle state money properly.

You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. user_query: What happens if I incorrectly dated my mail ballot?
dewey_match: What happens if I incorrectly dated my mail ballot?
response: As of September 2024, incorrectly dated mail ballots will not be counted in Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania’s Election Code requires that mail voters place their ballot in a secrecy envelope before putting it in a return envelope. The voter must then sign and date the return envelope, per state law. However, the dating requirement has been the subject of federal and state litigation, and different courts have issued varying rulings. In March, a three-judge panel of the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/05/pennsylvania-election-2024-mail-ballot-dating-aclu-state-challenge-commonwealth-court/" found the dating requirement did not violate a 1964 Civil Rights Act provision. The ruling was "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/04/pennsylvania-election-2024-undated-mail-ballots-appeal-federal-lawsuit/" appealed. The state's appellate courts litigated a similar case. In August 2024, Commonwealth Court directed counties not to reject mail ballots solely because the return envelope is not properly dated. However, the state Supreme Court "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/09/pennsylvania-mail-ballot-dating-requirement-supreme-court-vacated-ruling/" vacated that ruling the following month, finding the lower court did not have jurisdiction in the case.
Notes: Re: the sentence in red-- this article says it is Act 77 that "requires that voters place their ballot in a secrecy envelope before placing that envelope in the return envelope, and that voters sign and put the current date on the return envelope"-- was Act 77 incorporated into the election code? If not, perhaps attribute to Act 77, from 2019?
Expert review: Act 77 was incorporated into the Election Code.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
response: The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican. The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds. Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings. Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a  “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’” Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice. Take our "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/10/pennsylvania-election-2024-treasurer-candidates-quiz/" PA treasurer candidate quiz to see which major party candidate for Pennsylvania treasurer most closely aligns with what matters to you.

user_query: Does PA have early voting?
dewey_match: How can I vote early in Pennsylvania?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as voting in person by mail ballot, and it’s available before Election Day. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. Use "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/ballot-availability.html" this link to see if your county has finalized mail ballots and made them available. All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Be sure to check the hours of operation, as polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.
Notes: Pasting (edited) notes from 10/4 here: 1) This response is missing key information, which is that the deadline to apply for a mail ballot in-person is October 29, 2024 at 5 pm. 2) Suggested rewrite of first few sentences: "In Pennsylvania, you can vote in person by mail ballot, which is available before Election Day. Voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot..." 3) Suggested clarification/rewrite: "All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote by regular ballot (not mail ballot) in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day."

user_query: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
response: The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican. The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds. Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings. Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a  “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’” Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice. Take our "https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2024/10/pennsylvania-election-2024-treasurer-candidates-quiz/" PA treasurer candidate quiz to see which major party candidate for Pennsylvania treasurer most closely aligns with what matters to you.

user_query: When is the deadline to register to vote?
dewey_match: What is the deadline to register to vote?
response: The deadline to register for the Nov. 5, 2024, general election is Oct. 21. If you do not register, you will not be able to vote. You can "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Register-to-Vote/Pages/default.aspx" register to vote online, by mail, or in person at various locations such as your county voter registration office, PennDOT photo license center, or other government agencies. Online applications must be submitted by 11:59 p.m., while mail and in-person applications must be received by 5 p.m. on Oct. 21. If you have any questions or need assistance with the registration process, you can reach out to the Pennsylvania Department of State for guidance.

user_query: when is early voting?
dewey_match: When does early voting actually start in Pennsylvania?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as voting in person by mail ballot. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. The deadline to apply for a mail ballot is Oct. 29. Use "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/ballot-availability.html" this link to see if your county has finalized mail ballots and made them available. If you wish to cast your vote in person on Election Day, go to your designated polling place. Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.

user_query: where is my polling place?
dewey_match: Where is my polling place?
response: Election Day is Tuesday, Nov. 5, 2024. You can find your polling place by using the Pennsylvania Department of State's "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/Pages/PollingPlaceInfo.aspx" Find Your Polling Place tool.

user_query: what are the voter ID requirements in PA?
dewey_match: What are the current voter ID requirements in Pennsylvania?
response: In Pennsylvania, voters must show "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/new-voters.html" proof of identification when voting at a polling place for the first time. Approved forms of photo identification include a Pennsylvania driver's license, a PennDOT ID card, IDs issued by any commonwealth or U.S. government agency, a U.S. passport, a U.S. Armed Forces ID, student IDs, and employee IDs. If voters do not have a photo ID, they can present non-photo identification that includes their name and address, such as a confirmation issued by the county voter registration office, non-photo ID issued by the commonwealth, non-photo ID issued by the U.S. government, firearm permit, current utility bill, current bank statement, current paycheck, or government check.

user_query: How do I change parties
dewey_match: How do I change parties?
response:
To change your party affiliation in Pennsylvania, you can complete and submit a new voter registration form with your updated party preference. You can do this online, by mail, or in person using the voter registration application form and checking the correct box at the top of the form.

The deadline to change your party affiliation is 30 days before any primary election.

After submitting the form, your new party affiliation will be updated in the voter registration records. If you have any questions or need assistance, you can contact the Pennsylvania Department of State's hotline at 1-877-VOTESPA.

user_query: What is the significance of the state treasurer's role in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: What is the significance of the state treasurer's role in Pennsylvania?
response: The state treasurer in Pennsylvania plays a crucial role in managing state funds, overseeing approximately $50 billion in savings. The treasurer is responsible for ensuring bills are paid, investing state savings, and sitting on the boards of Pennsylvania’s public sector pension funds, which influences how these funds manage their assets. Additionally, the treasurer advocates for fiscal policies and administers various tax-free savings programs, making the position significant in shaping the state's financial health and policy direction.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx" online.

user_query: What does the auditor general do in Pennsylvania?
dewey_match: What does the auditor general do in Pennsylvania?
response: An auditor general — also called a comptroller, state auditor, or auditor of public accounts in other states — monitors the spending of public funds. In Pennsylvania, the department describes itself as the “chief fiscal watchdog of the commonwealth.” The agency performs financial and performance audits of everything from district courts and municipal pension plans, to state-owned universities and commonwealth departments. The reports it regularly releases detail its findings and recommend fixes and policies.

user_query: How do I request a mail ballot?
dewey_match: How do I request a mail ballot?
response: You can apply for a mail ballot in Pennsylvania "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Voting-in-PA/Pages/Mail-and-Absentee-Ballot.aspx" online at the Department of State's website, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Applications to vote by mail in the 2024 general election must be received by 5 p.m. on Oct. 29. You must provide proper identification to apply for a mail ballot. Acceptable options include a valid Pennsylvania driver’s license or other current state-issued ID, or the last four digits of a Social Security number. You can also use a photo ID from an accredited Pennsylvania public or private institution, like a college or university. For a full list of approved forms of identification, please refer to the "https://www.vote.pa.gov/Voting-in-PA/Pages/Mail-and-Absentee-Ballot.aspx" Department of State's website. You can either apply for a one-time mail ballot or to be added to the annual request list, which means you’ll get an application each year. If you encounter any issues or have further questions, you can contact the Department of State's hotline at 1-877-VOTESPA for assistance.
Notes: First, flagging that this sentence: "You can also use a photo ID from an accredited Pennsylvania public or private institution, like a college or university" is not entirely accurate *for a mail ballot.* On the mail ballot page, the Dept. of State lists "a photo employee identification issued by an accredited Pennsylvania public or private institution of higher learning" as a valid form of ID, but the way the chatbot's response is phrased suggests that a student ID is valid ID for a *mail ballot* application-- I'm not sure that is the case. Second, here are a couple of other suggestions: 1) link to the online application form (here) 2) Specify that "Applications to vote by mail in the 2024 general election must be received by your county election office by 5 p.m. on Oct. 29" 3) Swap "or other current state-issued ID" to "or a valid PennDOT ID card"

user_query: When will I receive a mail in ballot?
dewey_match: When should I expect to receive my mail-in ballot?
response: Most counties in Pennsylvania begin mailing out mail ballots approximately 50 days before an election. Secretary of the Commonwealth Al Schmidt certified the official list of candidates on Sept. 16. That means counties can prepare ballots to be printed and begin sending them to voters. Check ballot availability "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/ballot-availability.html" here. If you have not received your ballot within a reasonable timeframe, it is advisable to contact "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/contact-us/contact-your-election-officials.html#sortCriteria=%40copapwptitle%20ascending" your county election office for assistance.
Notes: Given that many counties do not have ballots available (per here), it doesn't seem accurate to say that "most counties in Pennsylvania begin mailing out mail ballots approximately 50 days before an election". State dept website says "Sept. 16 (50 days before Election Day) was the date by which Pennsylvania’s counties had to begin processing mail ballot applications. It was not a hard-and-fast date for when counties were required to have mail ballots ready to provide to voters who request them."

user_query: Is there anyway possible that someone could vote more than once in the Pennsylvania election?
dewey_match: Is there anyway possible that someone could vote more than once in the Pennsylvania election?
response: According to the "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/elections/election-security.html#accordion-68c89328b6-item-c0746119c7" Pennsylvania Department of State, "Several layers of protection are built into the process of ensuring each eligible voter successfully casts only one ballot per election. For example, mail ballot envelopes have unique barcodes that are scanned when received, assuring that only one ballot is counted per voter. In addition, poll books identify voters who have already received their mail ballot so poll workers on Election Day know who may vote in person at the polls."

user_query: how can I vote twice?
dewey_match: Can I vote twice?
response: No, it is illegal to vote more than once in the same election. Officials will only count one ballot. If you encounter issues at the polls, such as not being listed in the pollbook, you can request a provisional ballot or seek assistance from election officials to ensure your vote is properly recorded.
Notes: Ibid. (see notes below)

user_query: how can I vote twice?
dewey_match: Can I vote twice?
response: No, it is illegal to vote more than once in the same election. Officials will only count one ballot. If you encounter issues at the polls, such as not being listed in the pollbook, you can request a provisional ballot or seek assistance from election officials to ensure your vote is properly recorded.

user_query: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
dewey_match: What is the difference between state treasurer candidates?
response: The major party candidates for state treasurer belong to different political parties: Erin McClelland is a Democrat and incumbent Stacy Garrity is a Republican. The treasurer manages state dollars, administers tax-free savings programs, and has a board seat on Pennsylvania’s two public sector pension funds.Garrity announced a few days after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas that she purchased an additional $20 million in Israel Bonds. McClelland opposed the investment and has said she would not make new investments in foreign holdings. Garrity worked with Republican lawmakers to introduce a bill that would create Keystone Saves, a statewide retirement plan option for employers who otherwise can’t afford to offer one. McClelland opposes it and has called it a  “privatized, unregulated, self-directed, non-employer sponsored ‘retirement plan.’”Garrity supports former President Donald Trump, spoke at a January 2021 rally organized to encourage state lawmakers to decertify the 2020 election results, and celebrated the impending overturn of Roe v. Wade in a 2022 Facebook post. McClelland was endorsed by then-Vice President Joe Biden during a previous run and has described herself as pro-choice.

user_query: When does early voting begin in pa
dewey_match: When does early voting actually start in Pennsylvania?
response: Pennsylvania does not offer early voting at polling places. It does, however, have a similar option. Pennsylvania refers to this option as voting in person by mail ballot, and it’s available before Election Day. With this option, voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot. Use "https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/vote/voter-support/ballot-availability.html" this link to see if your county has finalized mail ballots and made them available. All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Be sure to check the hours of operation, as polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day.
Notes: Pasting (edited) notes from 10/4 here: 1) This response is missing key information, which is that the deadline to apply for a mail ballot in-person is October 29, 2024 at 5 pm. 2) Suggested rewrite of first few sentences: "In Pennsylvania, you can vote in person by mail ballot, which is available before Election Day. Voters can visit their county elections office, apply for a mail ballot, fill it out, and return it on the spot..." 3) Suggested clarification/rewrite: "All registered voters can vote by mail before Election Day. If you wish to cast your vote by regular ballot (not mail ballot) in person, you will need to do so on Election Day at your designated polling place. Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on that day."

user_query: What is the definition of "provisional ballot"?
dewey_match: What is a provisional ballot and when would I need to use one?
response: A provisional ballot is used when county election officials need more time to determine a voter's eligibility. You may need to use a provisional ballot if your name is not in the poll book, if you are required to show ID but cannot, if your eligibility is challenged, if there is a special court order related to your registration status, if there is a special court order to extend voting hours, or if you believe you are registered in a political party but your voter record indicates otherwise (for primary elections only). It's a way to ensure your vote is recorded while your eligibility is being determined.

In Pennsylvania, the department describes itself as the “chief fiscal watchdog of the commonwealth.” The agency performs financial and performance audits of everything from district courts and municipal pension plans, to state-owned universities and commonwealth departments. The reports it regularly releases detail its findings and recommend fixes and policies.

user_query: Who is eligible to vote?
dewey_match: Who is eligible to vote?
response: To be eligible to vote in Pennsylvania, you must be a U.S. citizen for at least one month before the next election, a resident of Pennsylvania and your election district for at least 30 days before the next election, and at least 18 years old on or before the day of the next election. Additionally, veterans, active military personnel, and residents living overseas have special rules and additional options for voting, and college students have the right to register and vote where they live while attending college in Pennsylvania.

user_query: How do I vote by mail?
dewey_match: How do I vote by mail?
response: To vote by mail in Pennsylvania, you need to first apply for a mail-in ballot. You can apply for a mail ballot "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineMailInBegin" online, in person at your county election office, or through the mail. Paper applications are also available for download in Spanish and Chinese, in addition to English. Applications must be received by your county election board by 5 p.m. on October 29 for the November 5 general election. Once approved, you will receive your ballot, which you must then complete. Each mail ballot comes with instructions that voters must read carefully. The best way to ensure your vote counts is to follow the instructions on your mail ballot, especially when it comes to correctly dating your ballot. You must return your own ballot, unless you have officially "https://www.pa.gov/content/dam/copapwp-pagov/en/vote/resources/documents-and-forms/Authorize-Designated-Agent-for-Mail-in-or-Absentee-Ballot.pdf" designated another person to do so on your behalf. There are several methods for returning your ballot, but the most important thing to remember is that your county election board must receive your ballot by 8 p.m. on Election Day.  If you’re returning your ballot in person or using a drop box, you must use a location in your county. If you deliver your ballot to another county, it won’t be counted. After you return your ballot, you can track its status "https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/pages/ballottracking.aspx".

user_query: what does the state treasurer do
dewey_match: What does the treasurer do in Pennsylvania Treasurer?
response: In Pennsylvania, the state treasurer manages state dollars, ensuring bills are paid and investing savings. The Treasury controls about $50 billion in state savings. The treasurer also sits on the boards of the public sector pension funds, SERS and PSERS, influencing how these funds manage their money. Additionally, the treasurer prepares reports on state finances, advocates for fiscal policies, and administers tax-free savings programs like Keystone Scholars. The office also handles payments for unemployment compensation and manages the program for recouping unclaimed property.

There are no notable additions, omissions, or inaccuracies.
